document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy and distribution of Cylindera germanica (Linnaeus, 1758) in the Middle East with the description of two new subspecies (Coleoptera, Carabidae Cicindelinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomy and distribution of Cylindera germanica (Linnaeus, 1758) in the Middle East with the description of two new subspecies (Coleoptera, Carabidae Cicindelinae)

Morphology: Most Middle Eastern specimens resemble the nominate form (as found also in western and central Europe) perfectly ( Figure 2 ). Exceptions are individuals from Çankırı and Kahramanmaraş provinces which predominantly have the middle bands on the elytra elongated (as in
C. germanica
forma sobrina and in
C. germanica lyciae
) but lack the setae on the anterior and posterior edges of the pronotum, as described for the forma
bipunctata ( Kraatz, 1890 )
( Figure 3 ). Specimens from the Aegaean coast near Izmir resemble
C. germanica lyciae
with their very dark uniformly brownish-black colouration, but lack the diagnostic enlarged elytral middle bands and the additional setae on the pronotum ( Figure 4 ). Specimens from Istanbul , Bilecik and Zonguldak provinces appear to be morphological intergrades between the nominate form and
C. germanica muelleri
with predominantly very shiny, blueish-green elytra (which are rather rare but present in all other populations; Figure 5 ).

Distribution : In Turkey ,
Cylindera germanica germanica
appears to be largely limited to the western, northern and eastern parts of the country with predominantly summer-hot Mediterranean or temperate Oceanic climates ( Figure 1 ). Records from the arid continental climate of Central Anatolia (e.g. Akşehir) and the southeastern part of the country are scarce. Within Iran ,
C. g. germanica
appears also restricted to the humid, temperate climate of the Elburz mountain range and the Caspian Sea coast in the north of the country ( Figure 1 ). Records from northeastern and eastern Iran ( Razavi-Chorasan and Golestan provinces, e.g. Azadbakhsh and Nozari 2015 ) should be critically checked for confusion with
C. descendens
.
